dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I always knew we were a fairly odd family. First there was me - too tall, too skinny, too orange - unfortunate hair. My mum was lovely, but not like other mums - there was something solid about her, something rectangular - her fashion icon was the Queen Mother - I never remember her not in tweed. Dad, well, he was more normal. He always seemed to have time on his hands - after giving up teaching university students on his 50th birthday, was always available for a leisurely cup of tea, or to let me win at table tennis once more. Then there was Mum’s brother, Uncle D. Always impeccably dressed, he spent the days just, well, being Uncle D. He was the same age as Mum but by the time I was 8, he was really my younger brother. And then finally, there was Catherine, Katie, Kit Kat. Ina household of suits and hair cuts, there was this - what can I call her - nature thing. With her big oval eyes, her wild hair, her purple t-shirts, her torn jeans and her eternally bare feet - she was then and still is, to me, about the most wonderful thing in the world. All in all - it was a pretty good childhood - full of repeated rhythms and patterns - charades in the winter, with me always losing - (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: croquet with Uncle D every summer - and by the time I was 21, we were still having tea on the beach every single day, no matter what the weather...

dialogues.speaker: DAD LAUGHING AT IT ALL, KIT KAT IN PURPLE T-SHIRT AND TOR
dialogues.text: JEANS —- MAKING A FIRE WITH STICKS FOUND ON THE BEACH, TR

dialogues.speaker: TO LIGHT IT, PUTTING ON AN OLD KETTLE. ONE CUP OF TEA TAK
dialogues.text: ABOUT HALF AN HOUR. A SCONE DROPS IN THE SAND - TIM’S MOT

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then every Friday evening - a film.

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: TO DRIZZLE —- AND UP GO SIX UMBRELLAS - NO-ONE MOVES. KIT JUST RELISHES THE RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then, once a year, the ghastly New Year’s Eve party...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN DANCING WITH PECULIAR, UNWARRANTED CONFIDENCE -
dialogues.text: TIM’S FRIEND JAY. WE SEE TIM SORT OF SMILING HOPEFULLY AT

dialogues.text: CUT ON - TIM IS JUST TRYING TO GET THROUGH THE NIGHT -—

dialogues.speaker: AS TIM HOLDS POLLY'S HAND, WE SEE A TEAR APPEAR IN THE CO
dialogues.text: OF HER EYE. FOR HER, IT’S A PROFOUNDLY SAD MOMENT - NO-ON

dialogues.speaker: BAD START TO THE YEAR.
dialogues.text: INT. TIM’S BEDROOM. MORNING. 3

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so I woke up the next morning, hung over, ashamed of myself and not realising it was the day that would change my life forever. KIT KAT ENTERS IN THE PURPLE T-SHIRT SHE SLEEPS IN.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Wake up, Stupid. Dad wants you.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Ah, Tim, come in... Do sit down.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: This is all very formal.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Well, yes, ahm, this is an odd moment for me - because I had exactly the same moment with my Father, when I’d just turned 21 - and after it, my life was never the same - so, I approach it pretty nervously.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay - when you're ready. All very mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright. Right. Tim - my dear son - the simple fact is that the men in this family have always had the ability to... This is going to sound strange. Be prepared for strangeness. But there’s this family secret - and the secret is that all the men in the family can - travel in time. (HEADING ON FAST)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, more accurately, travel back in time. I mean, once we’ve travelled back, we can of course travel forward back to the present, but we can't travel into the future from now. CUT BACK TO TIM. HE IS PERFECTLY STILL. THEN...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: This is such a weird joke...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It’s not a joke.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s got to be a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It’s seriously not a joke.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So you're saying that you, and granddad, and his brothers... could all travel back in time?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And you still do?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay - if it’s true - which it isn’t...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Although it is...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Although it isn’t, obviously. But if it was, which it’s not...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Which it is...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Which it isn’t - but if it was, how would I actually..?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: The 'how’ is the easy bit in fact. You go into a dark place - big cupboards very useful generally - toilets at a pinch - then you clench your fists like this, think about the moment you’re going to, and you'll find yourself there. After a bit of a stumble and a rumble and a tumble.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: .»..is as good a reaction as any. I think I plumped for 'fuck'. But it was the 80s.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I just take a few moments to think about it?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Please do. I’1l just be here. TIM HEADING OUT.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No - no - this is so obviously just a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It’s not. Why would I lie?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, I mean, there’s obviously only one way to settle this.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yes. Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But when I come back downstairs - after standing in a cupboard with my fists clenched - you’re going to be in so much trouble. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s see, shall we? And Tim... Try to do something useful. You want the first time to be interesting at least.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So much trouble. I mean it. Really. INT. TIM’S BEDROOM. DAY. 5

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND JAY
dialogues.text: You okay, Tim?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Good, good.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You're welcome, Polly. AND HE HEADS OFF INTO A DARK ROOM, OFF THE PARTY ROOM... INT. TIM’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 7 HE’S BACK IN THE CUPBOARD AGAIN. HE LOOKS AT HIS WATCH -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've actually never done this before.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: But then no-one has ever really kissed me before - so I thought, if I'm going to lose my virginity with someone, it might as well be you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Great news.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: I told Mum I was going to stay at Shirley's - so we've got all night. This (HER BODY) is yours for 12 hours. Do with it as you will, Tim Lake.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Great. Great. Will you just give me one second?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Of course - ‘man stuff’.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I really AM sorry.

dialogues.speaker: IS UTTERLY CHANGED.
dialogues.text: INT. FATHER’S STUDY. DAY. 9

dialogues.speaker: HE HEADS DOWN INTO HIS DAD'S STUDY
dialogues.text: HIS ARMS IN AMAZEMENT —- ‘WHAT THE HELL’ - DAD SHRUGS HIS SHOULDERS - ‘WHAT DID I TELL YOU?’

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Does Mum know?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Not a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Strange. And what about the whole. .?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Butterfly effect thing - what can I say, we don't seem to have messed up civilization yet...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a complicated year.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It’s going to be complicated life. Any ideas how to use it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, it’s going to take a lot of thinking about - what have you done... with it?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: For me it’s books, books, books. I've read everything a man could hope to. Twice. Dickens three times. And music of course.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDS
dialogues.text: And then, I've got to spend more time with you and the family. What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, apart from changing this haircut, money would be the obvious thing.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Very mixed blessing. Utterly fucked up your grandfather's life - left him without love or friends. I've never bumped into a genuinely happy rich person.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But it would be nice not to have to work.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: No - that’s a real recipe for disaster. Look what happened to your Uncle Fred.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What happened to Uncle Fred?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Nothing. Absolutely sod all. Wasted his life. You have to use it for things that will really make your life how you want it to be.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well. I suppose, to be honest, for the moment, I really just hope it's going to get me a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Wow. Big one.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yup - the mothership.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For me, it was always going to be all about love. Of course - there were some old scores to be settled....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIM’S HAIR IS A BIT DIFFERENT - IT’S A YEAR BACK, HIS FIN

dialogues.speaker: TUTOR
dialogues.text: Well, we draw near the close of your ignominious time here. I wish you all the best, although I fear the worst. God help the legal system if you lot are entering it. TIM RAISES HIS HAND...

dialogues.speaker: TUTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, Lake, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Can I just say, sir, on behalf of all of us, that we also wish you the best - but fear the worst. You’re the worst teacher any student has ever had - you’re not only stupid, you’re arrogant, aggressive, sleazy and wouldn’t recognise an original thought if it gave you a tender and caring blow- job.

dialogues.speaker: TUTOR
dialogues.text: You are in such trouble, young man.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Or not. Excuse I’m just popping to the toilet for a moment... INT. TIM’S ROOM. DAY. 13

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it was in the summer holidays, that the real business began. I walked downstairs and into love.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. THE HOUSE. DAY. 14
dialogues.text: KIT KAT’S LITTLE PURPLE CAR ENTERS THE DRIVE - TIM MOOCHE

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Charlotte, this is Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No it’s not. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Charlotte, this is Tim.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Hi, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hi, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I think you know my brother.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Jimmy Kincade.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: You don’t like him?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No - he’s - he’s a character.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Your sister loves him. TIM IS PUZZLED.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: True - not many guys will sleep with you on the first date.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You slept with Jimmy Kincade?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Wow, you really don’t like him.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Excuse me a moment. Can do better. THE CAR DRIVES BACK IN...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Charlotte this is Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hi, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I think you know my brother, Jimmy Kincade.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O yes, what a guy. How is the old bastard?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was heaven. And staying the whole summer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Wow - nice pyjamas. I’ve never met anyone who wears a pyjama.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really? What do people wear in bed these days?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: T-shirt and boxers. Or nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. CUT BACK INSIDE HIS ROOM. HE’S NOW WEARING A T-SHIRT OVER

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Hey. I had you down for a pyjama kind of guy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. T-shirt and boxers. Or nothing, of course. KIT KAT COMES ALONG THE CORRIDOR.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Why are you wearing that?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What happened to your penguin pyjamas?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Pyjamas? Not me. No. Bloody hell - pyjamas - come on!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: We thought we might head to the beach. Coming?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yup. Be right there. HE DOES NOT MOVE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Tim, will you do my back? SHE HOLDS OUT SOME SUNCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Absolutely. HE BOUNCES UP.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Wow. Keen. HE’S A BIT EMBARRASSED. HE TAKES THE CREAM, HOLDS IT OVER

dialogues.speaker: BACK... SHE SCREAMS. CUT RIGHT BACK...
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) Tim, will you do my back.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sure - give us a sec... HE READS A FEW MORE LINES (IT’S TOUGH TO DELAY, BUT HE DO

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Nice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT’S DINNER - TIM, AS EVER, FOCUSSING ENTIRELY ON CHARLOT AND EVERYTHING SHE DOES. THEY ARE EATING SOUP.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: What flavour is the soup?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Cauliflower.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Ah - the only problem with cauliflower I find, is that it tastes like cauliflower. CHARLOTTE LAUGHS A LOT AT THAT.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Excuse me one minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What flavour is the soup?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Cauliflower. TIM JUMPS IN...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The only problem with cauliflower, in my humble opinion, is that it always tastes like cauliflower.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: O, I quite like it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was the summer from heaven - it was the summer from hell. I invited my friend Teddy round for tennis because I knew he’d make me look good.

dialogues.speaker: AND TINY SKIRT. KIT KAT IS MORE INTERESTED IN MAKING SHAP
dialogues.text: THAN SHOTS —- BUT CHARLOTTE IS VERY GOOD.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately Charlotte just made both of us look like idiots. How the hell are you meant to concentrate on your game with this sort of shit going down?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It never got better - until it was almost too late.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Well, Charlotte, our final lunch - it's been lovely having you all summer, hasn't it, Uncle D.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Lovely having Charlotte here all summer.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Who is Charlotte?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Come on darling - Charlotte. Next to you.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Ah yes - Charlotte - lovely to meet you - how long are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I'm leaving today.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Alas - would have been wonderful to get to know each other.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Charlotte - as it’s the final day - the last night, can I... ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Ask away. O no - wait - it's not going to be about love is it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Kit Kat warned me about this and said that if you ever mentioned it, I should be very firm and say that you must treat me like a sister and not be stupid. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or have I made a total fool of myself and you were going to ask me for last minute tennis tips?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, it was about... the other thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Well, that's very sweet of you.

dialogues.speaker: HIM DEEP IN THE EYES. THINKING... HIS LIFE IN HER
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) Shame you left it till the last night - you should have tried creeping along the corridor while we still had time.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Last night a bad idea?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Last night a very bad idea - seems like an afterthought. Last night was never going to work.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. Good.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO THE UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR THAT NIGHT. TIM EMERGES CREA
dialogues.text: FROM HIS ROOM —- AND EDGES TOWARDS ANOTHER DOOR. HE OPENS DOOR GENTLY... AND WALKS IN....

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, yes - there is just one thing - I know you’ve probably suspected this - but in the last fortnight, I have fallen completely in love with you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, obviously, this was going to happen, because you’re the prettiest girl in history with the prettiest face and the prettiest hair... but even if, you know, you didn’t have the face and you had, absolutely no hair for some bizarre reason, I’d still adore you - not in a schoolboy way, in a really profound adult but not threatening way, and I just wondered whether by any chance you might share my feelings?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Wow. Ahm. I tell you what. Why don’t you ask me again on my last night?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Your last night.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Yeh. Try me on the last night. Let’s see what happens then.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. Perfect. Just perfect. HE STANDS OUTSIDE THE DOOR ALONE. AND KNOWS THE TRUTH.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so the love of my life drove, just drove away. All the time travel in the world couldn't help me there. And the next day it was my turn to leave.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Don’t spend it all at once, son.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I caught the train to London and headed for my digs, staying with an old friend of the family, who had apparently fallen on slightly hard times and needed the rent. It turned out to be just a few yards from Abbey Road - fans lining up by the crossing and risking their lives to have their photos taken...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you want?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm James' son.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: James Lake.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm his son. He said you had a room.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Go in there - and wait. Quietly. I mean it - don't make a fucking sound. 24 INT. HARRY’S HOUSE. DAY. 24

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: No - it's gone. I was actually having the first good idea I've had for a year, when you rang on the doorbell - and now it’s gone. You little shit.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: It's upstairs. The room. How's your Dad? Weird cock I always thought - something weird about him...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Never really liked him actually. Your Mum still look like Winston Churchill? That by the way is my wife. (PASSING A PHOTO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't like her at first - sarcastic cow - but eventually you'd realize she was the best human being in the world. Which is why she has left me, of course.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we go. Try not to make too much noise - particularly when having sex.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No chance of that. HARRY LOOKS AT HIM SCORNFULLY.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Christ. Two losers in one house.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's my daughter. Have sex with her if you like. Apparently everyone else has. INT. HARRY'S HOUSE. MORNING. 19. 25

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so I began my adventures in the legal trade.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a strange world, full of very strange people, both nice...

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m Rory. Very pleased to meet you. A real thrill. Who knows - we might become, you know... pals etc.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And nasty.

dialogues.speaker: TAVERNER QC
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I’m Tim Lake.

dialogues.speaker: TAVERNER QC
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you’re better than this clown.... Come on, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: It's Rory actually. I’ve been here a year. And a half. (TO TIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only saying that to be nice - it’s two years actually. HE EXITS FULL OF TERROR, PULLING A DESPERATE FACE AT TIM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are lots of things that time travel can’t help with. On the other hand - it’s extremely helpful in actual exams.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO TIM IN A TOILET COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: INT. TIM’S ATTIC ROOM. DAY. 29

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For a while I tried to sublimate my search for love to getting a proper job - though it's not easy. Come exams, the girls all look like Kate Middleton. But I still just looked like me.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: First night of my play Thursday - do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do you know - I'd love to - but I've got a date.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Really? A girl at last? The sad virgin's rocks finally get offed.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. It's a friend coming up from home. Male.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Urgh. Ditch the pervert.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd like to, but it's his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Please yourself. Anyway - the play's total crap - you're better off out of it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I bet it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t patronise me. I know shit when I see it. And when I write it.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: It's going to be weird to the max - but it's going to be mighty. This is a birthday dinner you will never forget. The Jayman does it again for tiny Tim and his tiny todge.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No lights at all?

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: None - the waiters are - wait for it - blind.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You are fucking kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: I am fucking kidding you not. As bats! As bats! INT. ‘DANS LE NOIR’ RESTAURANT. NIGHT. 33 THE MOODILY LIT FRONT DESK AT “DANS LE NOIR”. A DARKENED CORRIDOR HEADS DOWN TOWARDS THE PITCH DARK RESTAURANT.

dialogues.speaker: MAITRE D
dialogues.text: Julian will show you to your table.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Lead on, maestro. JAY PULLS A FACE AS A BLIND WAITER APPROACHES...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'll go for the meat menu, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Give me the fish, Juliano. God, I wish you had breasts, Timmo, no-one would see a damn thing. I could fondle you the whole meal.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, do you mind if these young ladies sit beside you - it is the only spare table.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: No, please do. Our honour and delight. Ladies, asseyez-vous.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Hello, gorgeous. A VERY CONFIDENT VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: And hello to you - it's my birthday and I'm very handsome.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (EMBARRASSED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O Christ.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Hello. I'm Tim.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm Mary.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O. That's my mother's name.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know, but I would've thought that was quite bad - because no-one wants to sleep with their mother - so if someone's got your mother's name, that's got to be an initial turn off, initially.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That's never occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. Well, good. It'd be worse if I looked like your mother. Unless your mother's very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: She's not. She’s rectangular.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. Or bad - for your Dad. I'm sorry for your Dad, but glad for you - and me, as it were. LITTLE AWKWARD PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How do you think the conversation is going?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really badly. Can we start again?

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jay is quite... enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I actually hate him. What's Joanna like?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Basically she's a prostitute. TIM LAUGHS. SOMETHING IS HAPPENING.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I think it's strawberry mousse. Do you want to try it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Where's your mouth?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Here...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: There?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, that's my nose, unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Okay, girls - be honest - who's more beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: MARY / JOANNA
dialogues.text: She is / I am

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Excellent. And I'm blindingly handsome - Tim's better seen through a haze of alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Actually, I look like Kate Moss.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. I look a bit like a mouse.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You like Kate Moss?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I've loved her all my life. Seriously. I'm actually wearing one of her dresses. You?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, her stuff doesn't look good on me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, what do you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O - yeah - very pretty - though, I wish she looked a bit more like a mouse. AND SHE LAUGHS AT HIM. IT'S PROBABLY LOVE. 35 EXT. ‘DANS LE NOIR’ RESTAURANT. NIGHT. 35 CUT OUTSIDE. THE TWO BOYS HAVE THEIR COATS ON.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: O my God - o my God - I am so in there. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know - but she sounded...

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: O my God, here they come...

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joanna?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Jay?

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: How wonderful to see you at last. Do you fancy some kind of clubbing experience? And then who knows - sex - possibly marriage...

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Sorry - we've got to rush off. But help me find a cab - then if you like, I'll give you my number.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: I like it very much.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hi. A SMILE. IT IS DEFINITELY LOVE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... it was lovely meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Would it be very immoral if I asked you for your number - just in case, you know, I ever...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO THE NUMBER NOW ON HIS PHONE. HE DELIBERATELY SAVES
dialogues.text: UNDER THE NAME ‘MARY X'.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Very good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Very good to meet you too.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: If anybody mugs me for my phone, I will absolutely kill him before he takes it and your number away. BIG SMILE. THEY WALK APART, THEN SHE TURNS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You really like me? TIM JUST NODS. AND WALKS AWAY. HIS LIFE TRANSFORMED.

dialogues.speaker: ENTERING THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: KITCHEN - AND THERE’S HARRY WITH HIS HAND CUT ON A GLASS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Nothing - just a flesh wound. You May remember, my play opened tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O my God yes - how did it go?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Well - it went well - very well - you could feel in the room a masterpiece was being unfurled.

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 37 PAUSE. 28.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Really. Until - and this is the crucial plot point, I think - until the lead actor had the most massive freeze in the history of theatre.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Yes. He didn't just forget his lines. He forgot his lines to an extent that no actor has ever forgotten his lines before in the annals of dramatic art. In the crucial courtroom scene. The reviews won't say “Major Masterpiece Gets Unveiled” - they'll say “Major Actor Gets Alzheimers”.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It's a disaster?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Is an understatement. It's a catastrophe. It's the Titanic of play openings. No survivors.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you mean ‘what you can do?’ - what you going to ring up every critic and offer them a blow-job if they ignore the fact that we sat in total silence for half an hour waiting for a moron to remember ONE LINE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not quite that. HE RUNS UPSTAIRS AND STANDS IN HIS ROOM, FISTS CLENCHED.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. ROYAL COURT THEATRE. NIGHT. 37
dialogues.text: FRONT OF THE ROYAL COURT THEATRE —- HARRY TOTALLY IN HIS

dialogues.speaker: ELEMENT. MUCH FIRST NIGHT EXCITEMENT. THE PLAY IS CALLED
dialogues.text: GUILTY MAN”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's it like, Harry?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Masterpiece, I'm told.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm just popping off for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm a friend of Harry's.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm afraid I'm rather busy at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I appreciate that. It's just, I thought - ahm, how's it going with the lines?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: 'The lines' - what do you mean 'the lines'?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It's just - you know - in the court scene - some of those lines are pretty complex - I thought it might be worth just, you know, having one last look at the lines before you go on - a little refresher...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here, you sodding lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And now - the Defence.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: I have been alive many weary years - but never, in that long catalogue of wasted time, have I ever seen such an atrocious miscarriage of justice...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I rest my case.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Do the Prosecution have anything final to add?

dialogues.speaker: PROMPTER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Gentlemen... NO USE... THE PROMPTER TRIES MORE...

dialogues.speaker: PROMPTER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I regard today’s proceedings...

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - Gentlemen, I regard today’s proceedings... BUT THAT’S IT - HE THEN FORGETS UTTERLY. SIR JOHN STANDS TRY TO HELP...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Does my honourable friend mean to say that he regards today’s proceedings with the utmost gravity? All the more so because a man's life is at stake?

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. BUT IT’S GONE AGAIN...

dialogues.speaker: PROMPTER
dialogues.text: Nevertheless...

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Nevertheless. (HUGE PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: Page 57.

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Excuse me, excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Do the Prosecution have anything final to add?

dialogues.speaker: THEN HE HEARS A COUGH. IT REGISTERS IN HIS EYES. THEN A
dialogues.text: ‘PSST' - AND HE LOOKS OFF STAGE FOR A MOMENT - AND THERE,

dialogues.speaker: FORGETFUL ACTOR
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. I regard today's proceedings with utmost gravity. All the more so because a man's life is at stake. Nevertheless let us be clear of one thing - it is the life of A Guilty Man...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: O look - and here's the little prick who walked out half way through. You missed the best scene, you twerp.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O no - fuck. EXT. ‘DANS LE NOIR’ RESTAURANT. NIGHT. 38 HOT AND HAVING RUN, TIM'S OUTSIDE “DANS LE NOIR”. HE CHEC HIS WATCH. IT'S 10.48.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Shit. Shit. (RUSHES IN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two girls in earlier tonight - one of them looked like Kate Moss - the other one like a sort of nice prostitute. Do you have their names?

dialogues.speaker: MAITRE D'
dialogues.text: O yes - no, I'm sorry, they were walk-ins and they paid by cash. Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Just the end of my life.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Cheer up, mate, apparently you're living with Britain's greatest living playwright. Don't usually read them - but couldn't resist this one. "Harry Chapman found Guilty - of genius.”

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I have to go out right now.

dialogues.speaker: AND AGAIN, THE NEXT DAY, TIM IN DIFFERENT CLOTHES. AND AG
dialogues.text: AND AGAIN - KIT KAT’S NOW SITTING WITH HIM. THE SEVENTH D

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Nice of you to keep me company, Kittle.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Nothing better to do.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How's Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Dumped me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not again. And work?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Sacked me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Idiots. Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Please. And muffins. I need treats.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does she actually look like, your future wife? Who you met at a party, and found out she liked Kate Moss but didn’t find out her number? AND SUDDENLY MARY IS ACTUALLY STANDING RIGHT BEHIND THEM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Soft face. Fringe. Bright eyes. The prettiest girl in the world. AND THEY WALK OFF IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: O my God. It's her.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. SHE TURNS. VERY EMPTY LOOK, OF COURSE - HE'S A STRANGER.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Great. PREGNANT PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We've never met before.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O no. Fuck. Of course we haven't.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You must've mistaken me for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. No. No. Your name's Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's a bit weird. How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You... look like a Mary. KIT KAT OBSERVING THIS SCEPTICALLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, my Mum's called Mary. HE ISN'T DOING WELL - AND KNOWS IT.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And I look like your mother?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not at all. Much prettier.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Right - well... great meeting you. Sorry, I've got to go - my friend's waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Absolutely. HE TURNS IN DESPAIR TO KIT KAT.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Very poor.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Very poor indeed. But let me handle it from here.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Coke-ee-dokee... But, you know, she looks cute. Two thumbs up from the English judge. CUT TO MARY - WITH HER FRIEND JOANNA. TIM REAPPEARS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Ahm, me again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Joanna, this is..?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Tim.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. I just had a weird experience with Mary here of thinking she was someone else I knew - but she wasn't BUT I just wondered if... I could walk round with you, because I'm... quite lonely.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about the girl you were with?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: My sister. She had to go. Somewhere interesting. We’re a very interesting family.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (TO JOANNA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should definitely say 'no'.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yes - this is dangerous territory.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All right. You have to promise you are not one of the following things - 1/ a lunatic 2/ a stalker 3/ worst of all - a bore.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. I'm just a big Kate Moss fan.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really? Do you agree the magic of her lies in her history - the informality of her early shots, compared to this stuff, so you always know, despite the high fashion, she's still just that same cheeky normal girl naked on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I do agree.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Milk?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No! You don't have a boyfriend!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't I look like I would have a boyfriend? (TO JOANNA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like I'd never get a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, no, I don't mean that. It’s just... I didn't expect - is he - quite a new boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. In fact - Rupert - over here.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rupert? A RATHER GROOVY, GOOD LOOKING YOUNG MAN APPROACHES.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Hi - sorry I'm late - with my Dad - he's very needy with Mum... gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This is Tim. TIM IS HATING THIS.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: How's the exhibition?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Gorgeous - she’s so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Never got it really. Not my type. THIS DOESN'T GO DOWN WELL WITH TIM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Who is your type then?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Her, obviously. TIM PULLS A FACE AT THAT. THEN A THOUGHT OCCURS...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So tell me, when did you two meet?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Only a week ago actually. It's been a bit of a whirlwind, hasn't it, poochy face? THAT'S EVEN WORSE. BILE GATHERING IN TIM'S THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm going to have to teach you what you can and can't say in front of people.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: "Poochy face' out?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Definitely out. And don’t even think about 'fuckbucket'.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: I would never call you '‘fuckbucket'.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. TIM AMUSED, THOUGH IT HURTS...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So, come on, more details. About the wonderful first meeting.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Well, okay, it was, what, a week ago - your birthday, Joanna...

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: June 10.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: And Jo was having a little party.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: My flat.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Which is where?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you - a detective?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, no - I just have a very visual imagination - I like to, you know, imagine stuff completely.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Meard Street, W 11 - 8.30 at night - will that do?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Excuse me - sorry - I've now suddenly got a bit of a tummy ache - watch out for those muffins - I'll be back in a tick.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O god - I should have thought this through. Erm... Rupert!

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - ahm - ahm - it's about your father.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: My father?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - ahm - I'm afraid he's in real trouble.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: What kind of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not at liberty to reveal that - but my strong advice would be that you go to see him straight away. RUPERT TAKES OUT HIS PHONE. TIM HAS TO ACT FAST.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But don't ring him first.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: He's not at liberty to make or receive phone calls, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - but who are you? - because there is a scenario here where you're a random lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. (DRAWS BREATH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then let me explain the actual scenario. I'm a plain clothes policeman and I'm doing you a fucking favour because I know how badly these things can affect the kids - so, risking my career, I'm telling you to move your posh arse in the direction of Paddington Police station. You weren't your Dad's one phone call because he called his lawyer because he doesn't want to rot in jail for 50 years - but now he desperately needs a friend - and my sources tell me you may be the only member of the family left, with your mother... gone. But, of course, you could just go get drunk instead, and leave him to suffer - miserably - alone - forever. RUPERT LOOKS AT HIM.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Paddington Police Station?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Paddington. Obviously. A FRIEND COMES BACK OUT TO THE STEPS.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on, Rupe? RUPERT LOOKS AT TIM WHO SHAKES HIS HEAD - 'DON'T BLAB'.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: It's okay. Nothing. I'll be back in an hour. Save me a drink. THAT ‘BACK IN AN HOUR’ WORRIES TIM A BIT.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suppose I should say ‘thank you’.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just doing my job, friend. A CAB FLIES BY - RUPERT HAILS IT. CUT INSIDE THE CAB.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Paddington Police Station.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Paddington. Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Tim.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: My mother's name. But let’s not get into that. You wouldn't like to come out to dinner with me, would you? Sometime in the next... hour.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's my friend Joanna over there - she’s much prettier than me - shouldn't you hit on her first?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, I like the look of you more.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Easier to get?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. Just generally preferable.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay - I might come, if you’re not crazy. Which you now have to prove.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, let's talk about Kate Moss.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I actually like Kate Moss.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I always think the key thing about her is the history. We all remember those fantastic pictures of her as a young school girl on a beach, so that even now, beneath all the glamour, we still see the wonderful young, impish amateur.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (AMAZED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is exactly right.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So - what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm a reader at a publisher.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No! You read for a living.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (SENSING HIS IRONY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - that's it. I read.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That’s so great - the rest of us, we just read, you know newspapers, books - but you, you get paid for it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's like someone asking, 'what do you do for a living?' - 'I breath, I'm a breather. I get paid for breathing'. How did you get that job?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay - what do you do, smartarse?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm a lawyer. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sexy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (GENUINELY SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think so - in a suit, in a court saving people's lives - that's quite sexy, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess it is. But not as sexy as reading. Sitting there, in your office, in a little chair - reading.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wait right there, mister. A lot of books get submitted to the publisher I work for, and it’s my responsibility to find out if any of them are masterpieces. No-one ever forgets the PWIDJKRALB.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The People Who Turned Down JK Rowling And Lost Billions.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Of course. Scary...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Exactly. So it's an IMMENSE responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I bet it is. And does this mean when you’re doing normal reading, it's ruined, because it's your job? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like prostitutes. I always worry that when they stop being prostitutes, they can't enjoy sex any more.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You always worry about that?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, I sometimes worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good - because someone who always worried about that would be a worry.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right - but, when you read a newspaper, do you think, “o fuck this - it's work”? Or a menu - 'I'm not reading this unless you pay me hard cash...” THEY ARE COMPLETELY ON THE SAME WAVELENGTH...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm going to go into the bedroom and put on my pyjamas.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: In about a minute, you can come in and take them off.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH IS HER BRA. HE REACHES ROUND TO TAKE IT OFF, B
dialogues.text: IT’S NOT EASY - LOTS OF UNHAPPY FINGERS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a front opener.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O yes - of course. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm sure it'll be better second time.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I thought it was pretty lovely.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, right, yes, it was lovely. Just give me... one minute.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ah yes - man things...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. You know your bras.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I like to think so.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wow. Well done - some guys make the most awful mess of it first time.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Pah - amateurs. Could you... excuse me just one second...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's like we've been together forever...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: If only. Best night of my adult life... CUT ON - AND OFF COMES HER PYJAMA TOP AGAIN. CUT TO THEM IN BED AGAIN. THEY ARE UTTERLY EXHAUSTED.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best night of my entire life. And now I've got a suspicion I'm going to have the best sleep of my life.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O really. So my perfect man is a typical man after all. Once is always enough.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that's completely fair.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just one more little kiss.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It's 4 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE NEXT MORNING. TOGETHER THEY’RE HEADING DOWN THE ESCAL

dialogues.speaker: BUSKERS
dialogues.text: How long will I love you? As long as stars are above you And longer if I can...

dialogues.speaker: 6/ RUSHING, REALLY LATE, THEY SPLIT ONTO SEPARATE PLATFOR
dialogues.text: — MARY MISSES THE TRAIN - ‘FUCK FUCK FUCK’. TIM SEES, AND LAUGHS .

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’ve got some bad news.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How bad?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Very bad.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You're dying?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not that bad?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm dying?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. My parents are dropping round.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O God. No. When?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Now now?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Now now.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do they know I exist?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have mentioned something like you - but nothing very specific.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do I live here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Definitely not.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Are we having sex?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, but probably not oral.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I wasn’t going mention oral.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well don’t.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How did you think that was going to come up?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m just saying - if it does, deny it completely.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Who's going to bring it up? Your Dad? “Tim - had any cunnilingus with my daughter recently?” MARY OPENS THE DOOR. THERE ARE THE PARENTS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Dad. Mum. O, and this is Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S DAD
dialogues.text: Shall we drop back when you haven’t got company?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s quite tricky - because Tim sort of lives here.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S MUM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. But no oral sex, I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Excuse me. THE DOOR OPENS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Dad. Mum. O, and this is Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Shall we drop back when you haven’t got company?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s quite tricky - because Tim sort of lives here.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. But in the spare room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: There isn’t a spare room.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. But in the spare bit of her room where she isn’t. In other words —- no sex. Of any kind. Especially not...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Coffee anyone? It’s a great morning drink.

dialogues.speaker: SHE LOVES HIM AND THEIR LIFE TOGETHER IS GOOD.
dialogues.text: INT. MARY’S ROOM. NIGHT. 48 BACK IN BED. BOTH LYING THERE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I've got tickets for the National Theatre tomorrow. Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So not. I'm just going to sleep all day.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I don't see why going to the theatre should get in the way of that. Many of the best sleeps of my life have happened in the Royal Shakespeare Company.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, take someone else.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What kind of sad act is going to be free on a Saturday night with no day's notice?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O my God. It's Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: My first real love.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: The old woman?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, not the old woman - the astonishing blonde.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: The one with dark hair?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No - blonde - blonde means with blonde hair. AND THERE SHE IS, EXQUISITE, MYSTERIOUS, IN THE CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay there - I mean it - stay.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: O my God - Tim. SHE GIVES HIM A HUGE, WONDERFUL HUG. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) Fabulous to see you. O - this is my girlfriend, Tina. A VERY PRETTY, SHORT-HAIRED, DARK-HAIRED GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (PUZZLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That is so brilliant - hello Tina.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: Why is it brilliant?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, you know there are certain moments in your life that scar you for life - and Charlotte's rejection of me was one of those moments - totally screwed up my self-confidence. But now I know she's got a... girlfriend that's suddenly a huge burden off my mind - I can be a confident heterosexual all over again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Not that kind of 'girlfriend'. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: You think I'm gay?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O. No. Of course. ‘girlfriend’ - yes. No. Wow. Friend who is a girl. So - I'm just going to get my boy- friend - I'm very keen you should meet him. AND BACK IN TIME AGAIN - TIM APPROACHES CHARLOTTE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: O my God - Tim. Fabulous to see you. (HUGE HUG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O - this is my girlfriend, Tina.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, Tina - though you should be a little careful with that, by the way. There are still quite a lot of us old-fashioned types who interpret 'girlfriend' as sort of meaning 'gay' so if you say Tina's your girlfriend, people will assume you're 'gay'.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: I am gay. Do you have a problem with that? PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, I don't. Love that stuff. BACK IN THE STALLS - JUST AT THE END OF THE PLAY.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow - I just saw the girl who broke my heart three summers ago.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Let's go say ‘hello'.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, best let sleeping dogs lie.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What did you think of it then?

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Brilliant. Best night of my year.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/OFF
dialogues.text: Tim. AND THERE CHARLOTTE IS AGAIN, IN ALL HER GLORY.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Charlotte. What a... surprise.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Good to see you. (SHE GIVES HIM A BIG HUG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my girlfriend Tina...

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: (BAD WHISPER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gay!

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Shut up. Hello, Tina.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: How great to see you. We're just off to dinner, but it'd be great to... hang out sometime.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, yes, great. I'd love that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Send my love to Kit Kat - how is she?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: She's fine. She's okay. Not finding London totally easy...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Jimmy tells me he sees her sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (NOT HAPPY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: There was always something there. And you are?

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: She means your name.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Rory. My name's Rory.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Rory.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: God she is beautiful. She's so beautiful if you had sex with her, you'd die. You'd just die - you'd open her shirt, you'd see her breasts, your eyes would explode. You'd have to have sex with her blind. And then you’d come. And then you'd die.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - but you notice she didn't give me her number... THEN SUDDENLY, THERE SHE IS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I told Tina to go have dinner on her own. You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sod off, Rory.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Okay - thanks again for the play. Gripping stuff. (CONFIDENTIALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know she's gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY’RE EATING IN A LOVELY OUTSIDE RESTAURANT. LOTS OF LAUGHING... TIM IS VERY HAPPY TO BE WITH HER.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I'm starting to think we slightly wasted that summer holiday.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hal

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: If we could travel back in time, maybe I wouldn’t have said ‘no’

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You didn’t say ‘no’ - you laughed. You went ‘ha ha ha’.

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 52 53 55. CHARLOTTE LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was it - that was exactly the sound - the sound of my confidence dying for a decade. LITTLE PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I’m just staying round the corner. EXT. CHARLOTTE’S HOTEL. NIGHT. 52 THEY'RE OUTSIDE HER HOTEL. CRISP SEDUCTIVE NIGHT AIR.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Do you want to come up? HE JUST STARES AT HER... UTTERLY BEAUTIFUL. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) Make up for lost time.

dialogues.speaker: PAUSE. HE IS VERY UNDECIDED WHAT DO TO. SHE IS SOOOOO PRE
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) So...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So... SO... (AND HE MAKES UP HIS MIND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So lovely to see you. Total joy. What a lovely night. I must get home - something important I have to do. Goodbye Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Would you like to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sssh - I'm trying to sleep - don't be so selfish.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. That went well, I think.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O God, I am SO late.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I've got something I really need to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes - come on - what? (CHECKING WATCH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so screwed.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I just wondered if you'd like, eventually, at some time in the future... to marry me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O my God. Ahm - SHE LOOKS AT HER WATCH. Really? You're doing this now?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm just popping out for a second.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O God I am so late.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: See you tonight then.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. 56 INT. MARY'S FLAT. NIGHT. 57. AGAIN... 56 TIM IN THE KITCHEN WAITING, NERVOUSLY. POISED TO PROPOSE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O God - I am exhausted. I’m just going to jump in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (RESIGNED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hand me another towel, will you?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I just have a little private moment?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BREATH
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t want to ask you to marry me when you’re just busting for a wee... A FEW MINUTES LATER - IN THE BEDROOM.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m all yours.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mary. AND ON GOES THE HAIR DRYER.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: O for Christ’s sake turn that fucking thing off and... THIS IS THE MOMENT SHE TURNS IT OFF. ...tell me whether you want to marry me or not?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry? Was that a marriage proposal?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not a very romantic one.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. You want more romantic?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Maybe just a little bit more romantic than “turn that fucking thing off and tell me if you want to marry me or not.” But, no, it has a certain rough charm...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I’ll be back in a minute. BACK TO HER IN THE SHOWER. HE OPENS THE CURTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think we should go out to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Isn't this gorgeous?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes - and a bit dangerous and I'm getting a bit cold. Shall we go back in?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just give me a moment...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going out for a walk - do you think you could turn on the lights in the garden?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And can I borrow a couple of coats?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is pretty gorgeous, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Gorgeous. Very romantic.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: God - what's this? There’s something in the pocket of the coat...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Let's see. Here have a look... HE TAKES OUT A LITTLE BOX, SHE OPENS IT - IT’S AN ENGAGEM RING.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O my God. Is this a proposal? TIM SMILES AND NODS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In a garden, under an arch, in the moonlight - could it be any more romantic?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, actually - give me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O my God. Is this a proposal? In a floodlit garden, under an arch - could it be any more romantic?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, actually...

dialogues.speaker: ARCH, ARE THE RESTAURANT JAZZ COMBO... AND THEY LAUNCH
dialogues.text: STRAIGHT INTO 'MY FUNNY VALENTINE’.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Slightly weird song for the occasion - ‘your looks are laughable, unphotographable’ .

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honestly, you should have just asked me one night in bed.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Don’t think I didn’t try. Any thoughts about the answer? 'Yes' / ‘No’ / 'Maybe' all possible. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think I'll go for 'yes’. Thanks for asking. Particularly cool since I'm actually pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm going to be full of surprises, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE THE DOOR OF THE FAMILY HOME. MARY’S A BIT NERVOUS

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Most important - if they offer you a cup of tea - just say 'no'.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Mum - this is Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Mary - pleased to meet you at last. Good lord, you're pretty.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't be stupid. It’s all just mascara and lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Let's have a look... O yes - good - lots of mascara - and very nice lipstick. It's very bad for a girl to be too pretty. Stops her developing a sense of humour, or a personality. Tea?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'd love a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Christ, that's the whole day gone.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What happened when Dad asked you to marry him?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: O, it was so romantic - I mean really extraordinary, very unlike your father. The sunniest day - music was playing - and a little child came running up and gave me a rose just after he asked me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Really - how lovely - how lucky, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (WITH A TWINKLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very lucky.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How many times?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Did you do the proposal to Mum.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: O God - I mean, 10. Took a fortnight.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O look! I'd forgotten this. My God - Jimmy Fontana. (AN OLD ITALIAN RECORD)

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Greatest song ever recorded by an Italian who looks like he has a dead badger on his head.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: And what are your faults?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Insecure.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Sweet.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Bad temper sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Crucial. How else are you going to get people to do what you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And I can’t hold my drink.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: That’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sometimes yes, sometimes no. Sometimes I sing, which is the ‘yes’, but sometimes I just fall asleep - that’s the ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: I hope we get lucky tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY IS STANDING IN FRONT ALL THEM ALL. SINGING ADELE’S “SOMEONE LIKE YOU” BOISTEROUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: “I heard that you’re settled down, That you found a girl, and you’re married now, I heard your dream came true...”

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (TO TIM )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love this girl... INT. GAMES ROOM. NIGHT. 63. 63

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Where’s Mary?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Sweet. Right - (TV COMMENTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what an extraordinary game this is - for the first time a father and son are playing each other in the World Table Tennis final - and neither of them are Chinese. Tremendous play by the old world champion and his son, the first openly gay British ping-pong player. But it feels like the youngster's beginning to crack - there are tears in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: There are not.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: There soon will be. A TRIUMPHANT SMASH. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. 64

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were here.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yeah, just popped up for a while.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What about the job? SHE WRINKLES HER NOSE - OBVIOUSLY THE JOB IS NO MORE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Wow. So life in London?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Horrid. Is Mary here?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Outside, I think. KIT KAT RUSHES OFF - HE CALLS AFTER HER...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be gentle - be gentle... BUT IT’S TOO LATE - KIT KAT CHARGES OUT THE DOOR - SEES M

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right - I've got an important announcement to make.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: O dear.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: What's the problem, D?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: It's the Germans, isn't it. War.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, it's not war, Uncle D. It’s that we've decided to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL SAY “HURRAY!”. KIT KAT SCREAMS WITH JOY AND ASSAULTS AGAIN. FROM THE GENERAL EXCITEMENT EMERGES UNCLE D.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Who are you getting married to?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mary here.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Thank God for that - would have been jolly embarrassing if it had been another girl. Imagine that - (TO MARY) you would have looked like a total gooseberry, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Can I say I've only known Mary for a few hours, but already I'm sure, in the event of a nasty divorce, I'm sticking with her, not Tim.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Thank you. O, and by the was... the wedding will be quite soon, because we're having a baby too.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: You're pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. KIT KAT SCREAMS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Good lord - who's the father?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tim here...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Thank God for that. Very awkward if it had been another fella...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We have to decide tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Everything you've refused to engage with. Best man. Honeymoon. Where we're marrying. How many guests.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We haven't decided any of those?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The only thing you've decided is that I will come down the aisle to the sound of an Italian weirdo singing a song called Il Mondo.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Excellent...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: To which I have said a definitive ‘no’. So here's the deal. I will take off one item of clothing for every decision you manage to make. This is a one off offer. Striptease, in your own living room, by a woman you think, by your own admission, is very pretty. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. You have my attention, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Right. Good. Where do you think we should get married?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Home - I’d hate anywhere else. OFF HER T-SHIRT, AND IS WEARING A BRA UNDERNEATH.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. Who should the priest be?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The local bloke with the yellow teeth and massive uni-brow...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay, that's a lock for Hagrid.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah. Right. I should have thought this through first.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I should have worn more clothes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So I better pick two really important questions. Best man.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Damn. I really want to see those breasts, but...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Best man. Now.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: This is SO hard. It's lose/lose - you piss off all the ones you don't pick and you end up hating the one you do pick because he makes an embarrassing speech and ruins your day.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you want to see these puppies or not?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (VERY TENTATIVE) Harry?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The breasts are the border from which no decision can ever return. Harry? Really? SHE REACHES BACK FOR HER BRA STRAP.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. Bad idea. He'll get drunk. Jay?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your choice.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: He's my best friend, but he’s a moron.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He will fuck up everything, yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Rory - he's boring - but he'll try SO hard...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sure?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Definitely. Rory. No, Harry. It's Harry.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay. It's Harry. WE SEE FROM BEHIND AS SHE FLICKS OFF HER BRA.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Actually, no - Rory.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That is such a cheat. But Rory it is - it's Rory and it can never change. Honeymoon? SHE PLACES HER THUMBS ON HER PANTS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Wow - this is turning into an exceptionally good night. I know this one! VENICE!!!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t think we can afford Venice...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Anywhere, anywhere literally....

dialogues.speaker: WE ALSO SEE BIG POLLY FROM THE BEGINNING
dialogues.text: ENORMOUS 6' 8” HUSBAND.

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 68 69. IT IS HIS REQUEST “IL MONDO”, A HUGE EPIC ITALIAN LOVE

dialogues.speaker: PURPLE WONDER.
dialogues.text: WHEN WE HIT THE SONG’S CHORUS, TIM’S DAD STARTS TO DO A

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO THE BRIDE AND GROOM KISSING AT THE ALTAR
dialogues.text: THUNDER - CLEARLY IT’S GETTING STORMY OUTSIDE - THE

dialogues.speaker: IT IS BROAD, REALISTIC, CHAOTIC COMEDY. ALL ACCOMPANIED B
dialogues.text: THE REMAINING, EPIC, ORCHESTRAL MINUTE OF ‘IL MONDO'.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: When Tim asked me to be his Best Man I was terrified, so I thought, well, the best thing is to finda book about speeches - and ahm, this is it and it says “think of really funny anecdotes” - and there IS one very funny story actually from work. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was quite a complicated case based on an issue of cross- amortization of ownership of post- divorce properties - and ahm - let me just explain the context - the defendant - a certain Mr...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: When Tim asked me to do his best man speech, my immediate reaction was - “how much are you going to pay me, you little shit? I don’t write for free, you know...” CUT BACK TO THE STRIPPING GAME IN THE FLAT...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm going to go for Jay.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yeh - he might be funny and I'm pretty sure we can rein him in...

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: These were the girls available in Tim's teenage years. SLIDE OF TIM AND, AROUND HIM, FIVE PHOTOS OF GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this is how far he got with each of them. THERE ARE NOW NUMBERS ON LINES BETWEEN TIM AND THE GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me explain the code. Zero - obviously nothing. Quite a lot of those. 5 - blow job. Only one, I’m afraid. AND BACK TO MARY AND HER BRA.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do you know, I know it's unusual, but I think I'll go for Dad. CUT TO DAD FINISHING HIS TOAST AND IT'S GOING WELL...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: And so, a toast to the man with the worst haircut, but the best wife in the room. THEY ALL LAUGH AND CLAP AND TIM SMILES AT HIM.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish I'd said that I love you.
