dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You did, Dad - it was implied...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I'm not sure 'implied' is good enough for a wedding day, are you? PAUSE - THEY BOTH KNOW WHAT HE MEANS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Don't do it - it's fine - I'm really happy with it as it was - you really don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I'll do what I want to do, young man. CUT BACK TO THE NEW SPEECH...

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My natural instinct of course is to try to be funny about my son - so many flaws - plays table tennis like a hairy goat, has never quite mastered the art of shaving. But always important, first, to say the one big thing. I’ve only loved three men in my life - my Dad was a frosty bugger - so that only leaves dear Uncle D - Nat King Cole, of course - and this young man here. I'd only give one piece of advice to anyone marrying. We're all quite similar in the end, we all get old, we all wrinkle, we all tell the same tales too many times - but try to marry someone... kind. And this is a kind man - with a good heart. I'm not particularly proud of many things in my life - but I'm very proud to be the father of my son. AFTERWARDS, BACK IN THE SWING OF THE PARTY...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Well done, Daddio. I thought you'd probably just joke your way through it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I was tempted to - but decided not to. This time. BE A LITTLE WORRIED ABOUT KIT KAT AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Kit Kat?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: O yes - I'm good, very good. Orange juice, no vodka - or is it the other way round? SHE TOASTS HIM IN VODKA.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: You next, Kittle Kattle?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I don't know Uncle D. Boys aren’t very nice.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Aren't they, darling?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Not in my experience. Always taking liberties. Not giving much back in return.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: O dear.

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE FACT THAT KIT KAT WAS AT HOME WHEN THEY ANNOUNCE
dialogues.text: THEIR PROPOSAL, AND THAT SHE’S JOBLESS, IT IS STARTING TO A NAGGING WORRY, THE DIMMING OF THIS GORGEOUS GIRL. CUT TOWARDS THE END OF THE RECEPTION...

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry to disturb you - but I wonder if I could have your autograph.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: No - no! Fuck off. It's a wedding for God's sake. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm here to celebrate true love - not to hand out stupid bits of paper with my illegible signature on it that you can flog on eBay, so at the next wedding you can afford to buy a less hideous hat.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I see you've met my mother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: O God - (TO HER) you might have told me. People should wear name tags.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER IN LAW
dialogues.text: What would you have said if you'd known?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: ‘Sod off’, rather than ‘fuck off’, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Do you wish we'd picked another day?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not for all the world.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: “And I-I-I will always love youououou...”

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O Jesus. It's coming.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Jesus. What do we need? Ahm...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I've done it all - it's all in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Nappies? Phone chargers?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Everything. Every single thing. Just get the car. All you have to do is drive me to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: To the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Which is in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay - stop the car.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Is it coming? (THE BABY...)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, it's not coming. I just want to point out you just had one job, that's ONE. The keeping fit, I did - the preparing the nursery, I did - the packing the bag, I did - the carrying the alien in my sodding stomach for nine years, I did. Your ONE AND ONLY job after impregnation was driving me to the hospital. Do you actually know which hospital we're going to?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Which hospital?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Ahm...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Either St. Mark something or Paddington something?

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For God's sake - do something. There's a head appearing between my legs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Christ - Abbey Road.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Could you just, you know, hurry up?

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE PERSON
dialogues.text: Abbey Road. Beatles. John, George, Paul... Lingo.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Fast as you can.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Terribly sorry, but, could you just... THEY IGNORE HIM.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN 1
dialogues.text: I'm not taking the picture - I want to be IN the picture.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN 2
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not doing it - I didn't come all the way from Minnesota just to be holding the goddamn camera.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Look, I'll do it - okay. Jesus - be careful.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. The thing is, though, that my wife is having a baby...

dialogues.speaker: NORTHERNER 2
dialogues.text: It's not going to be any bloody good anyway, Dave, with only three of us - it's going to look stupid.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Look, I know what...

dialogues.speaker: NORTHERNER
dialogues.text: You've got to take your shoes off...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (UTTERLY PANICKING) What?

dialogues.speaker: NORTHERNER
dialogues.text: Paul wasn't wearing any shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What. The. Fourfold. Fuck. Are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I know it seems - it was really complicated - I promise this was the quickest...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O my god - it really is coming noW...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Abbey Road! HE POINTS TO THE STUDIOS AND RUNS IN.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sorry. My mistake.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's better.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. I think it's coming.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Cool - I've finalised the route. The car is outside on a special parking metre. St. Mary's Paddington, here we come... And I think we should avoid Abbey Road.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Posy?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Posy she is. The most beautiful girl in the world.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one can ever prepare you for what happens when you have a child... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When you see the baby in your arms and you know that's your job now. No one can prepare you for the love and the fear. CUT TO TIM WATCHING AS POSY RESTS IN HIS MUM'S ARMS.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: O she's lovely. You were such an ugly baby. I remember the first time I looked at you, I thanked God we were in driving distance of London Zoo.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Come on, he wasn't that bad.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: O don't be silly... But look, the past is the past, the nightmare is over, he grew up human, the days of suckling a simian are a distant nasty memory. Uncle D, do you want a hold?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: O yes please...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (NERVOUS) Ahm, do you think that's...? Yes, sure. Sure...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are other things, of course - no one can prepare you for the bad nappies... MARY AND TIM IN THE LIVING ROOM. THEY HEAR THE BABY CRY..

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Let me do it, darling.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't you do this one - I've got a big case tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: O MY GOD. Where did this all come from?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one can prepare you for the love people you love can feel for them...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're okay?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I would like to babysit for her every single day of her life. I want you to die at the restaurant so I can take over forever.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And nothing can prepare you for the indifference of friends who don't have babies...

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, great, very pretty. Anyway - she's 18 years old, 18. I swear, she does not even OWN a bra... I've never seen her indoors in trousers. Just legs up to there and tiny, tiny pants...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And nothing can prepare you for how small a place that seemed a good size suddenly becomes... THE FLAT IS JUST FULL OF PRAMS, NAPPIES, FOOD, BABY BED..

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And how quickly you have to move to a place you can’t quite afford.

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 78 80. THEY ARE IN A SPARSELY FURNISHED NEW GARDEN FLAT.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's just the sheer shock of the pure unconditional love for this human fluke that happens to be yours... INT. TIM AND MARY’S HOUSE. DAY. 78

dialogues.speaker: CUT ON MONTHS
dialogues.text: STREAMERS, LITTLE HAND DRAWN SIGNS SAYING 'I AM ONE!!”. T ARE THERE PREPARING CUPCAKES - AND THE DOORBELL GOES.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That'll be your Mum and Dad. Bizarrely early as ever.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, Mum, Dad. Uncle D. Wonderful to see you. Come on in. And look, if it isn't Godfather Rory... RORY IS CARRYING THE LARGEST TEDDY BEAR IN HISTORY.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Only two important things for a godfather, I reckon - tell the child never to eat anything bigger than its head. And never bring a present smaller than the child.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: O shut up. HARRY IS THERE TOO, WITH A VERY SMALL BEAR.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: I didn't expect to see you here, Harry. Children's parties not exactly your style.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I was tricked. I was told there'd be free booze. Hate kids, as you know. For fuck's sake, Tim - I'm going to need straight vodka if there's a fucking clown coming.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We thought of having a clown but decided against it - best keep first birthdays small, just family, two friends, one giant stuffed toy.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Speaking of which, where is Kit Kat?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t know. She said she'd be here around three. THE DOOR BELL GOES.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil...

dialogues.speaker: BUT NOT NICE LOOKING YOUNG MAN. HE'S JIMMY KINCADE, WHO W
dialogues.text: FIRST SAW AT THE NEW YEAR’S PARTY, YEARS AGO.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jimmy - what can I do for you? And where's my sister?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I thought she was here.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No - she never arrived.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That's not good.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What does that mean? What does ‘that's not good' mean?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's a song by Baz Luhrmann, called Sunscreen - and I've never forgotten two lines from it - “Worrying about the future is as effective as trying to solve an algebra equation by chewing bubblegum. The real troubles in your life will always be things that never crossed your worried mind.”

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: We had a fight. And maybe I wasn't completely sober.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It was tea time. On a weekday.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I know. Very poor. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I blame Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: It’s so not his fault.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, so you say...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not good. When did she leave you? And from where? I want it exact - exact time, exact address.

dialogues.speaker: PASSING NURSE
dialogues.text: That's a broom cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I know. I love ‘em. CUT BACK TO THE FRONT DOOR, FOUR HOURS EARLIER.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You cut it fine.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sorry - I had to pick up Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (WHISPERING TO TIM)
dialogues.text: She couldn't come herself?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, as it turns out, she couldn't. CUT BACK TO THEM AFTER THE PARTY. RELAXING IN THE CHAOS..

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm worried about Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know. She was drinking vodka while we were drinking tea. And Jimmy wasn't nice to her.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We have to do fix it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We can’t do that. If it’s going to be fixed, she has to fix it herself.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Darling Kit Kat...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: How do I immediately know I'm about to be ticked off?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You're not. But I AM a little worried...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What did I tell you? It's a full- blooded ticking off.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It's just, you know, this is a strange place for you still to be coming all the time. Here with Mum and Dad and Uncle D...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: My best friend.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Indeed. But, what's happened? You're the best person in the world. Top equal with my wife. And the dog in The Artist. I don't quite get it.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Neither do I. TIME FOR THE TRUTH. SHE DOESN'T LOOK AT HIM AS SHE TALKS.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought life was going to be so great. But somehow up in London, in the real world, I keep getting knocked about...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And getting drunk.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: So sometimes I get drunk. And Jimmy’s unkind. So I come back home.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What happened with Marcus? He seemed a nicer guy than your usual.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I messed up - had an abortion - and he left. PAUSE, TIM IS MORTIFIED.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And so you end up back with Jimmy. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Maybe, just maybe, Tim, I'm the faller. Every family has someone who falls, who doesn't make the grade - who stumbles, who life trips up. Maybe I'm our faller. AND SHE GIVES HIM THE LOVELIEST SMILE IN THE WORLD. INT. TIM’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 81

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yes, Stupid?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You know I've spent my entire life taking the piss out of you because you believe in total crap.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Horoscopes...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Are brilliant...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Acupuncture...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Can cure any medical problem.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The Electric Light Orchestra...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Are the greatest band of all time. Except the Monkees, of course.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Exactly. All your beliefs, total codswallop. But, oddly, you may have had a point after all. I'm going to tell you a secret - but you have to keep it.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: We've always kept secrets.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We have.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: You put your willy into Jenny Arbuthnot.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I know. Thank you for never telling anyone.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I don't think even Jenny knew. PAUSE. KIT KAT LOOKS AT HIM AND SHRUGS HER SHOULDERS. BIG STOP. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what's the secret?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You promise you won't ever tell.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yes. BIG PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I can travel in time.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be so completely and utterly and totally great if you could?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Why are we standing in the cupboard under the stairs?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Because we're going to go back in time - and you are going to do some things differently...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: You are really funny - I love it when you’re funny.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hold my hand. WE SEE THEIR HANDS CLENCH.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: THE DOOR AGAIN. THEY'VE BOTH SEEN IT’S THE NIGHT OF THE N YEAR'S EVE PARTY YEARS AGO, THE VERY START OF THE FILM.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: O my God. O my godigod. I was right all along. Everything’s magic. Anything can happen. OUTSIDE AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are kidding though - I can go back anywhere in time and you bring me back to the worst party of all time?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: ‘Fraid so.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Though at least I met Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: My point precisely.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER GIRL
dialogues.text: Hello, Tim. THERE IS A SLIGHT AWKWARDNESS BETWEEN THEM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, Jenny. KIT KAT AND TIM EXCHANGE A LOOK...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: She still wants it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay - now we’ve got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What work?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We are making sure you do NOT meet Jimmy Kincade. And - quick - in here...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: But we have sex later.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not this time you don’t. ANOTHER FRIEND ACCOSTS KIT KAT.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: John - look, very important - don't go to Thailand - you'll get robbed and imprisoned.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Thanks Kittle - I have no intention of going to Thailand.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: No, but you do - seriously. And there are pictures of you all over the newspapers in a very tight pair of swimming trunks.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. Next door.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: But he’s about to tell me I’m the most beautiful woman at the party and put his hand down the back of my jeans.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Right. I get it. AND SHE MARCHES STRAIGHT OVER TO HIM.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Do we know each other?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yes, we do. Very well. And this is what I should have done right at the start.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy New Year everyone.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And now we leave.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: God only knows - but what I’m hoping is that from this moment on you avoid the sleazy bad guys - because they’re sleazy and bad. So you don’t spend your life feeling worthless, giving up every job on some bastard's whim, living in horrible flats waiting for the phone to ring.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Wow. When did you get so serious?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Since it occurred to me that I might lose you. PAUSE AS SHE REGISTERS HIS REAL CONCERN.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: And where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Back to the future.

dialogues.speaker: SWEEPER
dialogues.text: That's a broom cupboard, mate.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Thanks, I know. We can’t resist them. THEY STAND INSIDE THE DARK CUPBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: So, wait a minute, when we get back, will I remember the old life?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. I always do. But the new one is the real one - the old one is something you luckily escaped. CLEANER ENTERS TO SEE THIS SLIGHTLY STRANGE SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: CLEANER
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sorry - just give us ONE second.

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 86 87 88 91. HE TAKES KIT KAT’S HAND, CLENCHES IT...

dialogues.speaker: AND THEY ARE BACK WHERE THEY STARTED. THEY LOOK AT EACH
dialogues.text: OTHER.. THEN KIT KAT’S WHOLE NEW LIFE SWEEPS UP AT HER.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: O my god.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Teddy Frankman?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Yes. Wow. Surprisingly, you know - in bed. Right - let’s do this... THEY STEP OUT OF THE CUPBOARD. DAD WALKS PAST CASUALLY...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Come on, you two. Tea’s up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello gorgeous. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Immensely satisfactory.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Will you do dinner. There's something I've got to do before six or I get fired.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything I'd love to do more. HE GOES INTO THE NEXT ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is the most gorgeous person in the world? Come to your Dad and get food shoved into your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Dadda.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just stay there... little boy. And I'll be back in a minute. HE HEADS OUT INTO THE CORRIDOR.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you okay? You look like you've just seen a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. No. I’m great. HE ISN'T. HE HEADS INTO THE BATHROOM. CLOSES THE DOOR. CLENCHES HIS FISTS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Dad - can we talk for just a moment? HIS DAD COMES OUT INTO THE CORRIDOR.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't go back past this again, can I?

dialogues.speaker: RC ABOUT TIME
dialogues.text: 90 91 TIM NODS. 93.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: No, I should have mentioned that. The exact sperm at the exact moment - if you do anything the tiniest bit different, different baby. Chances are.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So every day up till yesterday is as it will always be? Lost.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Just like for everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay - okay. Interesting. Tough. Love you, Dad. Got to go.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Problem? INT. TIM AND MARY’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 90 IT’S AFTER THE BABY’S BIRTHDAY PARTY - IN THE DEBRIS OF T ROOM, TIM SITS WITH KIT KAT.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Kittle - I’m really worried.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Actually, we're going through a rather good patch. TIM LOOKS UP AT MARY - AS SHE PREDICTED...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I want to talk about Jimmy. I really, really think he’s a bad...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Influence, I know. But he’s good fun, and that’1l do me... Uncle D. I’m going to mash you, just mash you at croquet. SHE RUNS OFF. WE FOCUS ON TIM, IN TURMOIL.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. INT. TIM AND MARY’S HOUSE. DAY. 92 WE ARE BACK AT THE START OF THE BABY’S PARTY - EVERYONE T EXCEPT KIT KAT.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We did think of having a clown - Tim was particularly keen - but we thought Harry might kill him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I would have done, I hate the smiley bastards.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Better just have family. TIM ISN’T QUITE JOINING IN...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Speaking of which, where is Kit Kat? WE CUT TO TIM - HE GRITS HIS TEETH - AND THEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE KIT KAT’S CAR CRASH HAPPENING AGAIN. TIM HAS HAD T LET IT HAPPEN AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: You're still here.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. I’m not leaving this room till we find a way of making sure this never happens again. AN HOUR LATER...

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I'll drive more carefully.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Good start. But there’s more. Seriously. You have to work it out.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Me too. CUT TO THE NEXT MORNING. SAME SITUATION.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I'll have to stop drinking before teatime.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That too. Keep thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LATER ON THAT NIGHT. THE SWELLING HAS GONE DOWN A BIT
dialogues.text: KAT’S HAIR IS BACK TO NORMAL. SHE DOESN’T LOOK QUITE SO B

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: I have to leave Jimmy, don't I? And I have to stop drinking - and stop leaving jobs - and I have go out with someone nice and boring. AND TIM SMILES A SMILE AS WIDE AS A RIVER. LATER. HE’S A PREPARING TO LEAVE. And nice isn't necessarily boring.

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Like who? PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Matt Damon?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll go out with Matt Damon. And if he's married?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Pat Damon, his twin brother? Or Nat Damon, the youngster in the family. SCEPTICAL PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me. Do you remember Teddy Frankman?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just, you know, popped into my head. What's he like these days?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Okay. Quite cute looking - bit straight. Gets on well with the Damon family.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I’m thinking of asking him to dinner. You free?

dialogues.speaker: KIT KAT
dialogues.text: Might be... AND SHE GIVES HIM A HUGE SMILE BACK. AS HE LEAVES, JIMMY IS COMING INTO THE HOSPITAL CORRIDOR.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No! No! Out! Right now! You are so totally and utterly out of the picture I can't fucking tell you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Let's have another one.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Another what? O, screw that. One is enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortunately, we are young and fertile and it wasn't long before... 97 EXT. LONDON PARK. DAY. 97. 97

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that's another big strange thing - you pour all your possible love into one child... POSY, NOW GETTING BIGGER IS RUNNING TOWARDS HIM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And this is incredible, Posy Lake, only three years old, is about to break the Women’s Olympic record, if only her trousers can stay up... WHICH THEY DON’T. SHE TRIPS AND FALLS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then you have another one, and it turns out you've got exactly the same amount of love on tap... HE'S SWINGING HIS SON ROUND AS THEY WALK ON.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Love, this extraordinary ingredient that has no limits, ever expanding, self-reproducing. And all the time you love the woman you love as much as you ever loved her... 98 INT. TIM AND MARY’S HOUSE. EVENING. 98

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Darling, I'm sick with nerves. What do you wear for dinner with the greatest author in the country??

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'll settle the kids and come straight up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How about this?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Gorgeous. Job done. SHE CHECKS HERSELF IN THE FULL-LENGTH MIRROR TO HER LEFT.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. Take it seriously. I hate it. Makes me look lumpy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right. I hate it too. A SHARP CUT - SHE RE-EMERGES IN ANOTHER DRESS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about this?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Gorgeous. We did it!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not too breasty for Le Carre?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's too breasty.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. AND ANOTHER ONE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not too breasty.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, but I think high heels. Or my legs will look too short.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Which they aren't, but whatever makes you feel good. High heels are great. SHE NOW HAS THE HIGH HEELS ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wear high heels - it's not that kind of evening.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Not high heels then.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But then we have the short legs problem. CUT TO THE NEXT ONE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't think this one is too bad.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I think it's fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about the blue one? LITTLE PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The first one? The lumpy one that wasn't actually lumpy?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Which do you prefer?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm actually starting to go a bit mad now. SHE EMERGES IN THE ORIGINAL DRESS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go with this then. Although I think viz a viz breasts it's a bit disappointing. Where are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I left them downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not in the room with the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I don't think so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT INTO THE LIVING ROOM. IT IS A FIRESTORM OF PAPER — TOTALLY COVERED IN TORN AND COLOURED AND SHREDDED PAGES.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You are joking. You left them in here. With the only copy of the book in existence apart from the one on John Le Carre's computer. I'll be fired. The company will be fired. My life is ruined. TIM GOES TO WALK OUT OF THE ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay - take it easy - I'm just going to...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't you dare leave the room. If you leave the room, I'm leaving you. I mean it - face it like a man. Talk to me - how could you be so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I just have to...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And don't you dare answer that. What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sure we can, you know, reconstruct it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And how do you suggest we reconstruct this? (A FULLY CHEWED

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Well, no, that's not going to be particularly easy. May not be a very important page... PAUSE. THE PHONE RINGS ON.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really think we should...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you answer the goddamn phone, I will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: All right. I won't answer the phone. But I must just go to the little room... IS STILL RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: NO! “Sorry, Mr Le Carre - we've read most of your book - but the rest of it got eaten, or coloured in - or actually shredded.”

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - I had no idea Posy actually knew how to use that machine. In a way, it's impressive, though obviously not in a particularly good way today.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: WHAT DO YOU WANT? Okay. Sorry I shouted, Helen. He'll explain. It's for you. Your Mum. TIM THE PHONE. HE TAKES THE PHONE AND JUST LISTENS.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right - we'll come up. HE HANGS UP.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Dad. I'll call Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, he's not.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Hello Darling.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mum. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Honestly?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Fucking furious. I am so... disinterested in a life without your father.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: D. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: Do you know - I'm very well, though a little hot. But your father I think is not so well. Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: I'm very unhappy about that. At your wedding he said he loved me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE D
dialogues.text: I know. That was the best day of my life. So this is probably the worst.

dialogues.speaker: DAD'S STUDY.
dialogues.text: INT. DAD’S STUDY. DAY. 100

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: O for God's sake - not you too?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Well, Kit Kat's just rolled up blubbing her eyes out - and now you're here. What's Mum been saying?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The truth.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yes, well, apart from that. CUT TO THEM, SITTING IN HIS STUDY - THEY'VE BEEN TALKING.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't think I haven't tried. It may have been the smoking but I couldn't undo that, as it was before you were all born - and Mum definitely wouldn't have gone out with me at all if I hadn't been such a sexy smoker. I did get it found as soon as possible - but it was too late.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: O, you know, it could be years.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: How long really?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Weeks, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Have we had this conversation before?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I rather let myself down. Hugged you. AND TIM WALKS TOWARDS HIM - HIS DAD STANDS - HE HUGS HIM. HE EMERGES FROM THE HUG.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never said we could fix things. I specifically never said that. Life is a mixed bag, no matter who you are. Look at Jesus - he was the son of God, for God’s sake, and his life was still all a terrible old fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I know - but you must see, I feel a bit cheated.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Don’t - in fact feel the opposite - the only people who give up work at 50 are the Time Travellers with cancer who want to play more table tennis with their sons.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Right - so that was...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Sorry we had to call. It's suddenly got very bad - and Mum and I have been fighting it alone for quite a while.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Is there anything at all I can do?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I have thought of this one thing. If we're very careful. Just do it exactly the same...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: So. Tim. My son. Do you want to know the secret - or do you want to find it out for yourself - like I did?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: O Christ - there's not another secret?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Less dramatic. More important. The big one.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No - tell me. Let’s save some time.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Think about that thing I mentioned. Practice.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I will. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Mary. SHE HUGS HIM - HE WHISPERS.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've left everything to you. Don’t give him a penny.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thanks. The moment you die, I’m leaving him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What did you two talk about all that time?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Stuff. And you and Mum?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We decided it would be best if you never die. If you can work on immortality that would be great.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You’re such a wonderful woman. I’m so lucky to have you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What's your day tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Ghastly. Long, boring meeting. Very difficult case - very late night.

dialogues.speaker: THEN TIM RUSHES LUNCH... BUYS A SANDWICH FROM 'PRET A
dialogues.text: MANGER’.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hey Kit Kat. How's things? O Good - great. Look, I'm sorry, this isn't a great time. Maybe later. Okay. Okay. Well look, that's great - I'm really pleased. Wow. Great. Good old Teddy. Urgh. Honey - this is so not the right time - I'm needed in court in about five minutes. Okay. Yes. I'm going to have to go or I'll lose my job. Let's talk later. Okay. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: VERY WORRIED AND HE IS VERY TENSE
dialogues.text: THAT HE WANTED - ‘NOT GUILTY’ - AND, AS HE TIDIES HIS PAP HE SAYS TO HIMSELF “PHEW”.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Tough. Dull. Tense. Time for bed. CUT TO THEM IN BED.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Light off?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - though I might just pop to the bathroom first... CUT TO TIM IN THE BATHROOM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad, let’s give it a go. HE SHUTS HIS FISTS AND TRAVELS.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO LISTENING... AND WHEN THE OTHER LAWYER SAYS SOMET
dialogues.text: CLEVER SAYS “THAT IS A VERY GOOD POINT”.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Give me a second.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: We are really late.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Kit Kat. How's everything? You're kidding! You’re kidding! O Christ - I’m so sorry I’m in a tiny bit of a rush...

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDORS ARE GETTING EMPTY
dialogues.text: - but that is so great. Good old Teddy. Say ‘yes’ - even if you’re not sure - say ‘yes’. And yes - we are absolutely free on Thursday. I'm actually needed in court ten minutes ago, so can’t tie down ALL the details. But yes, my darling, I love you and this is great news. And I‘'1l ring you back a little bit later when I’m not about to give a close personal friend a heart attack. Bye, sweetie, bye.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND, BEAUTIFUL, LEATHER, CIVILIZED, ORGANISED.
dialogues.text: CUT TO HIS SUMMARY - “LADIES AND GENTLEMEN OF THE JURY” —

dialogues.speaker: WITH THE OVERJOYED CLIENT
dialogues.text: PROUD THEY ARE OF THEIR CORRECT DECISION. HIS EARLIER “PH NO CELEBRATION, JUST RELIEF - IS REPLACED BY “HURRAY”.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So, not as bad a day as expected?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, pretty good actually. Very good day really.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That’s a relief. If it’d been a bad day, I thought I might have had to have sex with you to make up for it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It was a very bad day. It went very badly. I lost my job. I killed a man. And I think I just heard one of our children die downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so I began to live the new life my Dad gave me. Each day, lived twice. Once with all the strains and tensions that stop us noticing how sweet the world can be - and once, well, noticing.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some days, of course, though, you only want once...

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Right - are we ready for this? HARRY COMES IN FROM THE NEXT ROOM, AND WALKS THROUGH.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Course we’re not. Hateful day.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Just give me one minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: This bit's very good - can I just read you this bit -

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Read away. We've got all the time in the world. PAUSE - THERE'S SOMETHING ODD IN THE AIR AS TIM SITS.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Where have you come from? THERE ARE TEARS IN TIM'S EYES.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay - okay. Thanks for coming. How's Uncle D's suit?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Immaculate.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Excellent. Mary’s dress?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Quite sexy actually.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Perfect. Did I mention I wanted that Stevie Wonder track?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes - all set.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BIG CAR IS DRIVING AWAY, WITH ALL OF THEM IN
dialogues.text: IT'S THE DAY OF HIS DAD'S FUNERAL. STEVIE WONDER’S JUBILA "YESTER-ME, YESTER-YOU, YESTERDAY” PLAYS. ll INT. TRAIN. DAY. 111

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Tough.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tough. Though I thought Jenny Arbuthnot looked cute in black.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: True. She knows how to excite a man. INT. TIM AND MARY’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 112

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What do you think about the kids?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not very many, are there?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I just thought. Maybe - you know - it's time for the insurance baby. In case one of them is really clever - we don't want the other one to spend their whole life feeling stupid - if we have another one, at least we could have two happy thickies.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You're so romantic.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What do you think? KNOW IT’S A HUGE DECISION FOR HIM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Cool. Cool. Dad always wished there had been more of us... And anyway - we might try and nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Could be tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And you cannot believe the detail in which I know the route to the hospital. Will you excuse me for a sec - there's something I've got to finish.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: O my God. I won. I haven't won for years!

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You finally got good.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What's my prize? Apart from the Olympic gold medal, of course? PAUSE. A BIG SMILE FROM TIM.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: A kiss will have to do.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: A kiss? A kiss?

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I get you. This is it then?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yes. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: My son.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: My Dad. THEY BOTH SMILE. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Or just one more game - I'd love to beat you twice.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It's never going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: “Who'd have thought it - father and son for the 28th year in the Olympic final - and young Tim suddenly looking like a broken man.”

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So now I'm almost up to date with my story. Sometimes, just for fun - I still bounce around -

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mum - surprisingly modern and good taste gift for you.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Open yours - it's even better.

dialogues.speaker: MUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I think it's GORGEOUS.

dialogues.speaker: NOW HOLDING THE IPAD, NOT THE HAT.
dialogues.text: Have you got one of these, Ted? TEDDY IS WEARING THE HIDEOUS HAT.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: No - I'd love one, but who really needs it, when you’ve got this hat?

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But in the end, I think I've at last learnt the full message from my strange adventures in time - the truth is I now don't travel back at all, not even for the day. I just live every day as if I I’ve deliberately come back to this one day - to enjoy it as if it was the full, final day of my lucky life...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll do the kids.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, don't worry - I'll do them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, you do them, lazy bastard.

dialogues.speaker: POSY
dialogues.text: You are the WORST.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: Want Mummy... TIM LAUGHS AT HIS NAUGHTY SON.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Hell of a day ahead.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We'll get through it.

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN CUT TO TIM AND RORY IN UTTER CHAOS RUSHING ALONG
dialogues.text: CORRIDOR, LATE AGAIN —- WHEN HIS MOBILE GOES. IT IS MARY.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What time are you home tonight?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: About 9, I hope. You?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: 6. What do you fancy for dinner, my hungry husband?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You decide.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Risotto?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What flavour?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Maybe chicken.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Chicken would be absolute heaven. HE HANGS UP, STEPS FORWARD. FREEZE.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVEN IS.
dialogues.text: ‘MOMENTS OF PLEASURE' BY KATE BUSH PLAYS OVER THE CREDITS
